structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course starts with the historical developments after the dissolution of the Soviet Union and then gives an overview of the past and present integrationist practices. It discusses competing projects of Eurasianism, pan-Slavism, and the "Russian world" as framers of different patterns of integration. After that, the course discusses EU-Russia rivalry in the common neighbourhood (Eastern Europe and South Caucasus), and ends up with the most recent trends in this realm.
description.et: Kursus algab ülevaatega erinevatest ajaloolistest ja tänapäevastest integratsioonivormidest Nõukogude Liidu lagunemise järel. Seejärel käsitletakse erinevaid ideoloogiaid, mis võiks seletada regionaalset integratsiooni endise NL aladel, ning EL-Venemaa rivaliteeti ühises naabruskonnas. Kursus lõpeb Ida-Euroopa, Kaukaasia ja Läänemere regioonide erinevate tulevikustsenaariumide üle arutlemisega.

objectives.en: The goals of the course are to introduce and relate to each other the concepts of regionalism and integration, and to discuss them in diverse political contexts related to post-Soviet countries. During the course students will  familiarize with different integrative projects and experiences of region-building in this area, as well as impediments and hurdles for regional integration.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on tutvustada ja seostada üksteisega regionalismi ja integratsiooni mõisteid ning arutada neid erinevates poliitilistes kontekstides, mis on seotud endiste NSVL riikidega. Kursuse jooksul tutvustatakse üliõpilastele erinevaid selle piirkonna piirkondade loomise integratsiooniprojekte ja kogemusi ning piirkondliku integratsiooni takistusi ja tõkkeid.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completing the course, a students will:
- demonstrate understanding of the different logics of integration in the post-Soviet region;
learning_outcomes.et: - demonstreerib mõistmist postsovetliku piirkonna integratsiooni erinevatest loogikatest;

learning_outcomes.en: - identify various concepts and ideas that explain Russia's and EU's policies in this part of the world;
learning_outcomes.et: - määratleb erinevad kontseptsioonid ja ideed, mis selgitavad Venemaa ja ELi poliitikat selles maailmaosas;

learning_outcomes.en: - focus on and compare the most important events defining the state of regional integration;
learning_outcomes.et: - keskendub ja võrdleb kõige olulisemaid sündmusi, mis määratlevad piirkondliku integratsiooni seisu;

learning_outcomes.en: - formulate an informed opinion about the current state of and new challenges to political and economic integration after the fall of the Soviet Union.
learning_outcomes.et: - sõnastab teaduspõhise arvamuse poliitilise ja majandusliku integratsiooni hetkeseisust ja uutest väljakutsetest pärast Nõukogude Liidu lagunemist.

notes.et: The course was developed and implemented with the support of the Jean Monnet module on The EU's Engagement with Russia and post-Soviet neighbors (EURUPN).

independent_work.et: Detailed instructions to individual work and assignments are provided in Moodle

description.et:
A - the paper demonstrates student's perfect knowledge of the reading materials and the course content, excellent writing skills, and contains conclusions relevant for the course. The academic / political controversies are duly described and commented
B - the student is familiar with the recommended literature, is aware of key concepts discussed during the course, and showed her/his ability to highlight its key points without getting into details and making comparisons with other similar cases or texts;
C- the student can engage with most of the academic arguments, is capable of analytically approaching the discussed topics and properly comprehend the main ideas of the course
D - the student is only superficially aware of the main issues touched upon by the recommended authors and the course instructor, and lacks a clear vision of the problems discussed
E - the student only scarcely discusses the key concepts in the literature and is minimally prepared for giving his/her expert opinion on the subject
F - the submitted paper is vague in language, or simply reiterates the well known facts, or is politically biased (for example, gives preference to one of many discourses or arguments), or is detached from empirical facts, or fails to cover alternative viewpoints existing in the literature or in political narratives. The paper lacks a clear structure or a concluding argument that summarizes the research.

GROUP-BASED PRESENTATION
A: the selection of the object(s) of analysis is well substantiated; the presentation is highly substantive and meaningful both in form and in content; it triggered further debate and provoked multiple questions, remarks and comments from other participants
B: solid and empirically relevant presentation supported by references to facts and literature; yet more descriptive than analytical
C: presentation is relevant yet its form is monological, more asking questions than giving answers or provoking further discussion
D: the presentation is informative, yet non-systemic (deviations from the main argument), repetitive and largely detached from the overall debate, with minimal cross-references to the extant literature
E: the presentation is too short and mostly rhetorical, with no substantial contribution to the academic discussion on the subject
F: the presentation fails to address core concepts of the course, and its content is limited to superficial and poorly substantiated points. Student fails to received positive assessment from his peers in the review process.

grade_preconditions.et:
Course requirements:
-  Attendance and participation in in-class discussions
-  Weekly home reading
- Completion of all three assignments with grades ranging from A to E

grade_evaluation.et:
The final grade is composed of the following elements:
50 % - policy paper
50 % - group presentations

debt_elimination.et: By individual agreement with the course instructors

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)
